and and if you test them young enough
before it gets even affected by language
so it's a way of seeing human nature um
in a very direct and sort of um

I'm as a developmental psychologist I'm

so this makes possible idea that our

they're not biological adaptations
they're accidents but I think they're
what make religious belief um attractive

Universal
Many religious people many people in

again
one-year-olds kids who just turned one

understand our evolved social capacity

over how we make our moral judgments and

Feelings by gut emotional reactions um

ation after demonstration of how

rich story but it seems inescapable that

not know this is happening and even in

if you read a developmental psychology

just ask the psychologist said what do

is children start off as realists about

um when they draw pictures and name them
they'll name them based on what it looks

until I had kids of my own and so the

an airplane it didn't look at all like
an
airplane and then I got to thinking and
I realize children draw all the time and

artwork doesn't look like anything until
they get old enough to get more
proficient so I wondered what was going
on and the idea which I explored and
this is with a a then student of mine
Lori markson we explored the question of
um whether children actually when
they're naming pictures are doing
something extremely smart when they're
naming pictures they're not looking at
what the picture looks like rather
they're trying to figure out what the

own pictures it's easy if Max was
intending to draw an airplane so it was
an airplane didn't matter what it looks
like we did experiments finding this is

like two-year-olds you um you look at us
at an object you make a picture but it's

notion of what kids know about art and

art linked up with Notions like artistic
intention and it's only later that they

it's only later that they might get the

this work on children comes from

when appreciating art so um so when

did she wanted to pick and um and this
is just a core part of how we name

how we appreciate artwork philosophers
like Arthur Danto point out that the
very notion of what art is as opposed to

art is is based on artistic intent
something can get
transformed from an everyday object to

of what people want it to be and in fact
in some other research I've done with

what is it and they'll say it's a mess
it's whatever but if you tell the same

their belief about how it was
created fiction is such a puzzle um you

there's two main reasons one reason is
um that our system that scans reality

what I can do to give myself pleasure is

they would probably prefer to have

to so one reason why fiction um is is

we seek out in fiction pleasure able
experiences that we would want to have
in a real world and it's close enough to

of fiction some of the stories we like
and this is a real puzzle um are
unpleasant people are drawn to tragedies

it's it's it's not hard to explain why I

Adaptive value to exploring in the

thinks ahead to well what's going to

Alternatives aren't always Pleasant ones
anybody preparing for a debate or

what a lot of fiction is is the

as a way to give voice to different

and different characters
and this shows up in its sharpest form

selves as when we become avatars on a in

if I'm passive I might explore what it's

think a useful function in that it's a

multiple parts of ourselves and that can

so you see this all the time in

exercises where you speak in different

gets a chance to explore different
facets of him or
herself so one interesting question is
in what ways um are children Superior to

lack and I think that there's two ways

which is what would you expect a child

one is developmental psychology and

that's better than adults and I think

you had better know a language and
there's not much Evol tionary pressure

you're you're done you should be knowing

better Learners regarding motor skills
possibly regarding certain aspects of
social
interaction um we'd be really screwed if

because I think we lose the plasticity
and
flexibility one claim which I'm not sure

Pretenders and better players than

is with
kids how pleasure Works explores the
pleasures of everyday life so it starts
off with seemingly Simple Pleasures like
food and sex and love and then it goes
on to Pleasures uh like the pleasure we
get from owning certain objects the
pleasure we get from reading books and
going to movies a pleasure we get from
art even the pleasure of religious
ritual and I focus on these Pleasures in
all sorts of ways and I say different
things about them but the main argument
of the book is that pleasure is deep
what I mean by that is that when we get
pleasure from something we don't just
resonate to its surface superficial
appearance we respond instead to what we
think that thing really is where it came
from what's its history what's inside it
so for sex it critically matters for
sexual arousal and sexual interest who
you think the person is do you think
it's a man or a woman is it a relative
or a stranger how old is that person
what's that person's sexual history all
of those factors invisible to the eye
have a deep effect on sexual interest
for food it matters enormously what you
think you're eating not just in sort of
a abstract conscious sense of what you
choose to buy or what you choose to to
put in your mouth but in how it tastes
um the the the price of food how natural
it is how healthy it is are all
considerations that affect um your t
taste experience of it the maybe the
most um practical application of this is
wine so there's now several studies
showing that the more expensive you
believe a bottle of wine to be um the
better it will taste to
you in some of my own work I've looked
at the pleasures of consumer products so
uh people will pay more for something
and will enjoy it more if they believe
it was owned by a
celebrity um if they believe was touched
by a celebrity in fact a way to make
such an object lose value is to wash it
thoroughly they don't want it wash
because it it washes off the essence of
the person who touches it um I got into
this work because I'm interested in a
claim that cognitive psychologists and

mind which is that we're common sense
essentialists when we understand
something like when we name it or

it we don't just respond to to what it
looks like uh we respond to what we
believe its deeper
Essences now this has commonly been
applied to more coldblooded tasks like

book because I was interested in the
idea that essentialism applies more
generally and that essentialism can help
explain a lot of some mysteries of our
everyday
Pleasures I think essentialism is an
important part of the story and it's
something which uh common theories of
pleasure tend to miss but I wouldn't
argue for a minute uh against idea or
other factors that affect pleasure so
one one factor affects pleasure is
simple experience um faces for instance
look more attractive the longer you look
at them something psychologists have
called a mere exposure effect when it
comes to music and art you often get
what looks like a sort of inverted
U-shaped curve so you start off when you
hear a new song you might not like it
that much then the more you hear it the
more you like it the more you like it
the more you like it until it reaches a
certain point where boredom kicks in and
now you don't like it anymore and a lot
of the sort of U-shaped curve shows up
for all sorts of things from uh the
foods we we eat to the books we read to
the people we encounter so I don't doubt
for a minute that there are low-level
processes like mirror exposure and like
simple sensory Pleasures that exist um
but my
the argument I make throughout the book
though is that we tend to overestimate
how much of our pleasure is determined
by these simple processes people believe
for instance that when they taste wine
the pleasure they get from wine um is
due to the chemical composition of what
they're drinking it's due to what's
hitting their tongue and their nose and
when you tell them that's not true that
their pleasure is easily manipulated by
telling them different things about the
wine like where it came from how much it
cost uh and so on people bulk at this
they say that might work for other
people but not for me I taste the wine
but one of the great surprises I think
from psychology is the extent to which
our everyday experiences are shaped by
our beliefs even in cases where we're
unconscious that we have these beliefs
or these beliefs are playing that
role a very hard question looking at
human differences to try to explain
their origin so some people um like
cheese I don't like it at all some
people are gay others are straight um
some people do radically different
tastes in movies and books um in artwork
in
ritual and I'll admit for the most part
